title: MUSIC MUS_THRY 405-0-20 Introduction to Research Methods in Music Theory and Cognition

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Introduction to Research in Music Theory

This course is an introduction to the research methods and scholarship of music theory, broadly construed. It will center around intensive, student-driven reading and discussion of current research. We will read widely across various areas within the field, considering questions such as the following:


  • What is the nature of evidence in the field of music theory?

  • What kinds of questions has music theory asked?

  • What kinds of agendas seem to inform or guide music theory (including unacknowledged ones)?

  • What kinds of representations are used in music-theoretical arguments? What do they represent?

  • What qualities and features are involved in an effective musical analysis? In what ways might analysis be involved in developing a larger argument?

  • What kinds of things can music-theoretical arguments accomplish? How might the scope of such arguments be expanded?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The course will be directed toward graduate students in the Music Theory and Cognition program, although other students with a strong interest in music theory are welcome provided that they have sufficient background and skills to engage with high-level scholarship in this area. Passage of the music theory diagnostic or successful completion of the theory review course is a prerequisite. Students wishing to enroll in the course should contact the professor to discuss suitability (mark-butler@northwestern.edu).
